article.title: Mass sensitivity of the three-flavor chiral phase transition

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1 shows the light and strange condensates as a function of temperature towards the chiral limit in the fixed-UV scheme. What happens to the condensates as the system approaches the chiral limit?
choices: The light condensate increases while the strange condensate decreases.
The strange condensate increases while the light condensate decreases.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 2 displays the behavior of the condensates and meson masses as a function of temperature towards the chiral limit using the fixed-f scheme. What is the order of the chiral phase transition observed in this scheme in the chiral limit?
choices: The order cannot be determined from this figure.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 3 illustrates the chiral phase transition in the (mπ, mK) and (μ, mK) planes within the extended mean-field approximation (eMFA). What is the effect of including quark vacuum fluctuations in the eMFA compared to standard MFA?
choices: It extends the first-order region in the light chiral limit for μ = 0.
It induces a second-order transition in the light chiral limit for μ = 0 when the axial anomaly is included.
It removes the tricritical point on the mK-axis for μ = 0.
It has negligible impact on the overall phase structure.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 4 presents the Columbia plot for μ = 0 with vacuum and thermal quark and meson fluctuations included within the FRG framework. How does the size of the first-order region around the chiral limit compare to the eMFA results?
choices: The first-order region is significantly smaller in the FRG results.
The first-order region is significantly larger in the FRG results.
The size of the first-order region is nearly identical in both approaches.
The FRG results do not exhibit a first-order region.
